foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 27 bis r

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 1r. Opening of Aristotle’s Peri Hermeneias (On Interpretation) in the translation of Boethius. You may recognize this page from the teaser of this exhibition. Aristotle’s On Interpretation deals with the relationship between words, reality and logic.
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 46r: opening of Porphyry’s Isagoge, an introduction to the Categories of Aristotle
Paris, BnF, lat. 14614, ff. 117-202 (the opening of the text is missing). Date: 12th century. The manuscript belonged to the library of St. Victor, Paris.

Paris, BnF, lat. 14614, f. 117r: Abelard, Dialectica. The opening of the Dialectica is missing, but an identification of the text is written at the top of the page: ‘scripta super predicamenta Aristotilis’.
Paris, BnF, lat. 16598: Augustinus’ Dialectica and John of Damascus’ Logica
Paris, BnF, lat. 16598, f. 37r: Porphyrian Tree
Paris, BnF, lat 16611: Porphyrius, predicamenta, periermenias, divisiones, sex principia
Paris, BnF, lat. 16611, f. 7v: Square of opposition
Paris, BnF, lat. 16611, f. 8v: Porphyrian tree
Paris, BnF, lat. 16611, f. 14v: Mnemonic device for the moods of syllogisms
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 218r: Opening of Analytica Posteriora
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 164v: Opening of Analytica Priora
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 17r (detail): Portrait of magister and student
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 69r: a column for commentary on the left of the tekst, and two columns on the right. The lower margin is also typically large to house large amounts of notes and comments
Paris, BnF, lat 2788 (ca 1000), f. 49r: Opening page of Aristotle’s Categories
Paris, BnF, lat. 2923 (mid 13th c.), f. 49r: Abelard, Apologia seu fidei confessio ‘Universis’ (1141)
Paris, BnF, lat. 6638, f. 6r: Square of opposition
Paris, BnF, lat. 7749, f. 33v: Victorinus’s commentary included a number of summary diagrams. Cicero’s text is added in red in the margins.
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 132v: 'Lady Dialectica' (left) lures in students (right).
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A f.127v: ‘Lady Grammar’ teaches a group of students.
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 140v: Portrait of Lady Rhetoric
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 151v: Portrait of Lady Astronomy
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 153v: Illustration of 'Lady Music'
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f.133r: The opening of Martianus’ chapter on dialectic, with Remigius' commentary (on the right)
Leiden, UB, BPL 144: manuscript made in the 12th century
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 2r: Opening of Boethius' Consolatio Philosophiae
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 62v: Opening with the text of Martianus Capella, De nuptiis
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 2r: Opening of Boethius' Consolatio Philosophiae
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r: Square of opposition
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r: Square of opposition
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8v: INCIPIT ARS DIALECTICA ALCHOINI PHILOSOPHI. AD KAROLUM MAGNUM
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 63r: List of propositions
Leiden, UB, BPL 84: On f. 8v we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection.
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 44v: two sets of rubrics (written in red) indicate that one text has ended and that another will begin on the next page
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8r: a decorated initial is used for the first word of a new text
Leiden, UB, BPL 84: Furthermore, a new set of quire gatherings starts on f. 17r; from this point to the end of the manuscript quires are numbered with numbers, not letters.

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 63r: ‘All that is just is good. All that is virtuous is just. Therefore, all that is virtuous is good.’ This syllogism joins two universal affirmative propositions (‘all that is just is good’ and ‘all that is virtuous is just’) and deduces the conclusion ‘all that is virtuous is good’.
f.94r Opening of Priscian's De Constructione with initial of Lady Grammar
f.143r The opening of the Pseudo-Ciceronian Rhetorica ad Herennium
f.166r The opening of Boethius’ translation of Porphyry’s Isagoge

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 29 (878), p. 165: Manuscripts were often ruled with a knife; here we can see on p. 165 that the blade has cut through the parchment while ruling the edge of the text block.
Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315 (605), p. 139: representation of Porphyry’s five predicables
Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315 (605), p. 53: this tenth-century manuscript contains one of the oldest examples of a ‘Porphyrian tree’ in a manuscript of the Isagoge.
St. Gallen,  Stiftsbibliothek, Cod.Sang. 128, p. 3: prologue to Jerome’s Commentary on the Epistle to the Galatians (c. 389). Manuscript made in St. Gallen, first third of the ninth century.
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 1r: The opening of Cicero’s De inventione
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 105r. Manuscript made in the twelfth century.
Karlsruhe, BLB, St.Peter perg. 92, f. 11v: Ramon Llull in discussion
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 6v: Aristotle's army
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 1v: Ramon receives his vision
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 3v: Ramon learns Arabic from his assistant
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 10r: Ramon is attacked by an angry mob. This single image depicts five different scenes.
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 7r
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 5r
Valenciennes, BM, Ms. 404, f. 27r. Manuscript made in Saint Amand in the ninth century.
Valenciennes, BM, Ms. 406, f. 2r: Opening of Cicero's Topica
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 31r: example of a very full commentary added in the margin. The book is 307 mm high.
